Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A familiar customer strolls in while the receptionist is free to chat.
Story: My phone buzzes on the counter just as I’m mixing color for Mrs. Lee, who’s always early for her Thursday appointment. I glance at the screen—an urgent message from my manager, asking for confirmation on tomorrow’s meeting with our external partner. I know leadership expects a quick reply, and I can already imagine the follow-up emails if I don’t respond soon. But at the same moment, Mrs. Lee walks in, smiling, and the receptionist is chatting with someone else. As her hairdresser, I’m supposed to greet her warmly, offer her tea, and make her feel at home. I can see her looking around, waiting for that familiar welcome. My fingers itch to type a quick response to my manager, but I also feel the weight of Mrs. Lee’s expectation for personal attention. My mind races, torn between the pinging demands of my inbox and the warmth I owe my client. I stand there, caught between two worlds, heart pounding, unsure which role to honor first.
